articles.headline: For Michigan’s Economy, Electric Vehicles Are Promising and Scary
articles.snippet: In a presidential battleground state, electric vehicles have emerged as a contested piece of the economic future — a job-killer or a job-creator.
articles.abstract: In a presidential battleground state, electric vehicles have emerged as a contested piece of the economic future — a job-killer or a job-creator.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last fall, Tiffanie Simmons, a second-generation autoworker, endured a six-week strike at the Ford Motor factory just west of Detroit where she builds Bronco S.U.V.s. That yielded a pay raise of 25 percent over the next four years, easing the pain of reductions that she and other union workers swallowed more than a decade ago.

articles.headline: Strongmen Find New Ways to Abuse Interpol, Despite Years of Fixes
articles.snippet: The international police organization has toughened oversight of its protocols, which autocrats have used to pursue dissidents. But the autocrats have adapted.
articles.abstract: The international police organization has toughened oversight of its protocols, which autocrats have used to pursue dissidents. But the autocrats have adapted.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, strongmen and autocrats had a novel weapon in their hunt for political enemies. They used Interpol, the world’s largest police organization, to reach across borders and grab them — even in democracies.

articles.headline: Spicy Food and Dental Implants: Low Prices Lure Hong Kongers to China
articles.snippet: Hong Kong residents are finding in Shenzhen, the mainland city next door, lower prices, better service and tasty cuisine.
articles.abstract: Hong Kong residents are finding in Shenzhen, the mainland city next door, lower prices, better service and tasty cuisine.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shuen Chun-wa, 81, and her husband hurried toward a green bus with two dozen other Hong Kong residents, dragging empty suitcases. They had purple tour stickers on their jackets and were headed to shop in Shenzhen, a bustling Chinese city that sits on the northern side of the border with Hong Kong.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson, Zixu Wang and Olivia Wang

articles.headline: Wall Street Is Already Placing Bets on the Biden-Trump Rematch
articles.snippet: Traders and strategists are thinking about all the ways that November’s election could alter the mood in markets.
articles.abstract: Traders and strategists are thinking about all the ways that November’s election could alter the mood in markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nine months ahead of the presidential election, investors are already thinking about how financial markets might respond to the outcome of the vote, and how they should trade to prepare for it.

articles.headline: Wife, Protector and Now Political Heir: Yulia Navalnaya Rallies Russians
articles.snippet: The wife of Russia’s most famous opposition leader long shunned the spotlight, but his death in prison may make that impossible. “I have no right to give up,” she said.
articles.abstract: The wife of Russia’s most famous opposition leader long shunned the spotlight, but his death in prison may make that impossible. “I have no right to give up,” she said.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was August 2020, and Yulia Navalnaya, the wife of Russia’s most famous opposition leader, was striding through the battered, gloomy hallways of a provincial Russian hospital, looking for the room where her husband lay in a coma.

articles.headline: Culinary Hubs Put a Twist on Home Cooking
articles.snippet: Developers are transforming clusters of old homes into micro restaurants to cater to the needs of surrounding neighborhoods.
articles.abstract: Developers are transforming clusters of old homes into micro restaurants to cater to the needs of surrounding neighborhoods.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nestled in the dense, residential Los Angeles neighborhood of Victor Heights, a tightly packed plot of Craftsman and Victorian homes has stood the test of time, serving as single-family residences in one of the city’s oldest neighborhoods.

articles.headline: Inside the Funding Frenzy at Anthropic, One of A.I.’s Hottest Start-Ups
articles.snippet: The company raised $7.3 billion over the last year, as the lure of artificial intelligence changes Silicon Valley deal-making.
articles.abstract: The company raised $7.3 billion over the last year, as the lure of artificial intelligence changes Silicon Valley deal-making.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last May, Anthropic, one of the world’s hottest artificial intelligence start-ups, raised $450 million from investors including Google and Salesforce. It was the beginning of an astonishing funding spree.
articles.byline: By Erin Griffith and Cade Metz

articles.headline: Will Food Prices Stop Rising Quickly? Many Companies Say Yes.
articles.snippet: Food companies are talking about smaller price increases this year, good news for grocery shoppers, restaurant diners and the White House.
articles.abstract: Food companies are talking about smaller price increases this year, good news for grocery shoppers, restaurant diners and the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: Few prices are as visible to Americans as the ones they encounter at the grocery store or drive-through window, which is why two years of rapid food inflation have been a major drag for U.S. households and the Biden administration.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Jason Karaian

articles.headline: Supreme Court Won’t Hear New Case on Race and School Admissions
articles.snippet: The decision, along with an order this month declining to block West Point’s admissions program, suggests that most justices are not eager to immediately explore the limits of its ruling from June.
articles.abstract: The decision, along with an order this month declining to block West Point’s admissions program, suggests that most justices are not eager to immediately explore the limits of its ruling from June.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court cleared the way on Tuesday for the use of admissions criteria intended to diversify the student body at an elite public high school in Virginia, declining to revisit the role race may play in admissions months after it sharply curtailed affirmative action programs in higher education.
